bibl.title: Letter from G. Glenwood Clark to Philip Showalter Hench, January 2, 1952

div1.p: Clark inquires if Hench has any information on the "Apache girl," called Susie, who was abandoned by an Apache raiding party under Geronimo. She was subsequently taken in by Reed and trained as a servant. Clark notes that Susie eventually left the Reeds and returned to Oklahoma, where she taught English to Apaches.

div1.head: Letter from G. Glenwood Clark to Philip Showalter Hench, January 2, 1952
div1.opener:
COLLEGE OF WILLIAM AND MARY
FOUNDED IN 1693
WILLIAMSBURG, VIRGINIA
G. G. CLARK
ASSISTANT PROFESSOR OF
ENGLISH & JOURNALISM
110 North Boundary Street
Williamsburg, Virginia
January 2, 1952
Dr. Philip S. Hench
Mayo Foundation
Rochester
Minnesota
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
May I trespass upon your good nature with a request
for some information which you may have? Perhaps in your col-
lection of books, letters, manuscripts, etc dealing with Dr.
(Major) Walter Reed, the discoverer of the true bearer of the
germs of yellow fever, you may have some reference to an Indian
woman in whose history I am at the moment greatly interested.

In the spring of 1878 Geronimo left the San Carlos In-
dian Reservation and raided on his way south to Mexico. U.S.
Cavalry, to which Reed was then attached, pursued the Apache
chief. At an adandoned Indian camp, Dr. Walter Reeed foundan
abandoned Apache baby girl. She was badly burned. Reed took the
waif to his own home. Later, the U.S. government ordered the
Reeds to train the girl, whom Walter Reed named Susie, as a
household servant.

From 1887 to 1890, the Reeds were stationed at the
Coast Guard Artillery post at Mount Vernon Barracks, fifteen
miles above Mobile, Alabama. Susie left the Reeds' home while
they were ar Mount Vernon barracks. Apparently, Susie returned
to Fort Sill, Oklahoma, where she taught her native Apaches
English. She died at Fort Sill about 1902.

Do you have any information or any reference in any
of your Reed material to this Apache, Susie? Do you know of any
published material about her to which you could refer me?

Any help you can give me in this matter will be greatly
appreciated.

With best wishes for a Happy and Prosperous New Year,
I am,
